title: Evaluation of the J2000 groundwater component
text:
6.1 Normalization with percentiles and median
Another approach to normalize the data is to use the 25th and 75th percentile instead of the minimum and maximum. After that the data is rescaled around the median.
\[
norm(value)=\frac{value-25Percentile(value)}{75Percentile(value)-25Percentile(value)}
\]
\[
resc(value) = \frac{norm(value)}{median(norm(value))}
\]

6.1.1 Time series








Figure 11: Time series of normalized and rescaled values







6.1.2 Regime








Figure 12: Regime of hydrological year

title: Evaluation of the J2000 groundwater component
text:
6.4 Z-score normalization
Z-score of a value is calculated with the mean (\(\mu\)) and the standard deviation (\(\sigma\)): \[
norm(value) = \frac{value - \mu}{\sigma}
\] This is also the same normalization used for the calculation of the Standardized Precipitation Index (SPI) or the Standardized Piezometric Level Index (SPLI or IPS in french). The SPLI was calculated in the Explore2 project for the output of the model AquiFR and the reference data, and the model was evaluated using the NSE.

6.4.1 Time series








Figure 17: Time series of normalized and rescaled values







6.4.2 Regime








Figure 18: Regime of hydrological year

title: Evaluation of the J2000 groundwater component
section: 6.5 Normalization with the minimum and maximum of overlapping period
text:
6.5 Normalization with the minimum and maximum of overlapping period
Same approach as the initial one, but not with the all time minimum and maximum but rather the minimum and maximum of the time period greater then the 50th quantile of the whole time period.

6.5.1 Time series








Figure 19: Time series of normalized and rescaled values







6.5.2 Regime








Figure 20: Regime of hydrological year





It’s really hard to decide visually for one normalization method.

title: Evaluation of the J2000 groundwater component
section: 6.6 Euclidean distance between the different normalization approaches and the ADES reference data
text:
6.6 Euclidean distance between the different normalization approaches and the ADES reference data
The euclidean distance \(dist=\sqrt{\sum{(x-y)^2}}\) was calculated for each approach (\(x\)) to the ADES reference data (\(y\)) for every plot (time series, regime, duration curve). The mean values of all stations are shown in Figure 21.








Figure 21: Mean euclidean distance between the normalization approaches and the ADES data for the different plots

title: About
text: This website is about presenting the interim results of the Evaluation of the J2000 groundwater component.

title: Evaluation of the J2000 groundwater component
text:
A cluster analysis for the regimes of all piezometers in the Loire catchment was conducted. The data was (so far) not checked. The monthly mean was calculated, then a z-score normalisation was executed and the longtime monthly mean calculated. Stations which inherited NAs afterwards were excluded for clustering.










Figure 1: Cluster dendogram for hierarchical clustering













Figure 2: Regimes for 4 clusters - Hierarchical clustering













Figure 3: Map - Hierarchical clustering
















Figure 4: K-means clustering results for 4 clusters













Figure 5: Regimes for 4 clusters - K-means clustering













Figure 6: Map - K-means clustering

title: Evaluation of the J2000 groundwater component
text:
2.1 K-means clustering
A total of 6 clusters were chosen to see if its possible to distinguish better between influenced and not influenced piezometers.








Figure 9: K-means clustering results for 6 clusters













Figure 10: Regimes for 6 clusters - K-means clustering













Figure 11: Ratio of max(actRG1)/maxRG1 and geological units of HRUs

title: Evaluation of the J2000 groundwater component
text:
2.2 Random Forest clustering
A Random Forest (RF) model was trained unsupervised with 5000 trees. The clustering was done using Partitioning Around Medoids (PAM) clustering for the proximity matrix of the RF output.

rf <- randomForest(x = df_m_wide2, ntree = 5000, proximity = TRUE)
prox <- rf$proximity
pam.rf <- pam(prox, 6)









Figure 12: Regimes for 6 clusters - Random Forest clustering

title: Evaluation of the J2000 groundwater component
text:
2.3 Clustering of duration curve
The duration curves were interpolated for clustering to obtain the same length of data for each station

# make wider and interpolate -> for same length of duration curves
df_durCur_w <- df_durCur %>% 
  select(code_bss, value_n, prob) %>% 
  group_by(code_bss) %>% 
  reframe(value = approx(prob, value_n, xout = seq(0,1,0.01))$y,
          prob = approx(prob, value_n, xout = seq(0,1,0.01))$x) %>% 
  ungroup() %>% 
  pivot_wider(names_from = code_bss, values_from = value) %>%
  as_tibble() %>% 
  select(-prob) %>%
  t()









Figure 13: K-means clustering results for duration curves





There are really low values in cluster 2 and nearly no high values.








Figure 14: K-means clustered duration curves
